coredata.dc:title: Deriving intrinsic electron-transfer rates from nonlinear Stern—Volmer dependencies for fluorescence quenching of aromatic molecules by inorganic anions in acetonitrile
coredata.dc:creator: Mac, Marek
Wirz, Jakob
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The fluorescence quenching of aromatic molecules by inorganic anions in acetonitrile was investigated by stationary fluorescence measurements. The dependence of the quenching rate constants, k q on the free energy of electron transfer, ΔG 0 et, obeys the well known Rehm—Weller expression which indicates that electron transfer is responsible for fluorescence quenching. Nonlinear Stern—Volmer behaviour was observed in many cases especially at very negative ΔG 0 et (< −0.7 eV). Distance-averaged electron-transfer rate constants, 〈k et〉, were determined from the concentration dependence of the fluorescence quenching rates using a procedure developed by Keizer. In three cases these values can be compared with those obtained by analysis of the transient effect seen directly in picosecond time-resolved fluorescence decay curves.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: volume 211, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 6August 1993 Deriving intrinsic electron-transfer rates from nonlinear Stern Yolmer dependencies for fluorescence quenching of aromatic molecules by inorganic anions in acetonitrile Marek Mac and Jakob Wirz Inst itur fur Physikalische Chemie der Universitat Basel, Klingelbergstrasse 80, CH-4056 Basel, Switzerland Received 8 April 1993; in final form 3 June 1993 The fluorescence quenching of aromatic molecules by inorganic anions in acetonitrile was investigated by stationary fluores- cence measurements. The dependence of the quenching rate constants, kq, on the free energy of electron transfer, AG24, obeys the well knnwn Rehm Weller expression which indicates that electron transfer is responsible for fluorescence quenching. Nonlinear Stern Volmer behaviour was observed in many cases especially at very negative AG, L (c 0.7 eV ).Distance-averaged electron- transfer rate constants, (k,,), were determined from the concentration dependence of the fluorescence quenching rates using a procedure developed by Keizer. In three cases these values can be compared with those obtained by analysis of the transient effect seen directly in picosecond time-resolved fluorescence decay curves. 1. Introduction In a recent paper [1] we gave evidence that the mechanism responsible for fluorescence quenching of aromatic molecules by inorganic anions in polar solvents is electron transfer from the inorganic an- ions to the excited aromatic molecules. We observed the formation of anion radicals of the aromatic mol- ecules and diiodide radical anions in acetonitrile. The dependence of the fluorescence quenching rate con- slants [1], calculated from the initial slopes of the Stern Volmer plots, on the free energy of electron transfer, has a typical Rehm Weller form [21; the quenching rates reach a plateau in the exothcrmic region of aG~ (up to 0.2 ev) and decrease when AG~, becomes more positive. Similar results were re- ported in previous papers [3 6]. In some cases we noted that the Stern Volmer plots have a positive curvature, i.e. that so-called static quenching becomes important at higher quencher concentrations. We observed no differences in the absorption, fluorescence, or excitation spectra due to added quenchers, indicating that complexation of the ground state aromatic molecules with the quenchers is unimportant. The amount of the static contri- botion was dependent on AG, ~ and on the fluores- cence lifetimes of the fluorophores. A theoretical ex- planation for such nonlinear Stern Volmer behaviour was given in papers by Keizer [7]. In this Letter, we analyze the nonlinearity of Stern Volmer plots in or- der to obtain distance-averaged electron-transfer rate constants, <ices). The values of <kt5) will be dis- cussed on the basis of electron-transfer theory. The discussion will also focus on the reliability of this technique in obtaining values of intrinsic electron transfer rate constants, diffusion coefficients, and encounter distances. 2. Theory Curvature in Stern Volmer quenching plots in- dicates that the S V slope, Ksvkqt4, is dependent on quencher concentration. Because the fluorescence lifetime, rX, in the absence of quenchers is by defi- nition concentration independent, kq depends on the quencher concentration. We will use the method of Keizer [7] to analyze the curvature in the Stern 20 Elsevier Science Publishers BY. Volume 211, number t CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 6August 1993 Volmer plots and give a brief summary of the rele- vant expressions here. The observed effects may be quantitatively de- scribed by introducing a pair distribution function, g(r), that describes the quencher concentration in a sphere with radius r around the excited fluoropliore. For steady-state measurements this function has the form kq I a 2ss 12 _____ ______ / ) + a exp(_rah/2) L 2(a fl) j where D is the sum of the diffusion coefficients of the aromatic molecule and the quencher molecule (D=DA+DQ) and N is the Avogadro constant in units of mmol1. The parameters a and ss are de- fined as ~ (1!t~+kq[QI )/DA and ss=(lJ1+kq[Q])/D. The latter parameters have an interesting statis- tical interpretation; the inverse root of a corre- sponds to the mean statistical displacement of the acceptor and the inverse root of ss corresponds to the relative displacement of the acceptor and quencher, during the lifetime of the acceptor. The bimolecular rate constant can now be calcu- lated as kq(EQ])=4xN Jk0(r)g(r)r2dr, where k (r) is the distance-dependent reaction rate constant. In the systems investigated here this is the rate constant of electron transfer. When the quenching is assumed to occur only at a fixed encounter distance R, the expression for the fluorescence quenching constant takes the form k 4icN DRk C(R) 4itN DRC(R)+k where C(R) is defined by DQ-DA C(R) = ~- exp( R/P 2) +~exp(_Ra~2). If we assume that DA=DQ and the electron transfer is allowed to proceed at distances greater than the contact separation, the equation for the observed (2) quenching constant may be easily derived from eqs. (I ) (3) and has the following form 4aN DJ~ k (r)r2dr 7 D+ f~k (r)exp( ra 2)rdr where a is the distance of closest approach of the reactants. For comparison with experimental fluorescence quenching data we use the standard S V relationship I~~~l+kq[Q], (8) (3) where k0 is given by eq. (7). If the transport process is very fast (D ~cc) the process is controlled by chemical reaction and the observable reaction rate is given by the simple integral kq(ket>~4~N Jk0(r)r2dr. (9) (4 Keizer has analyzed experimental quenching data based on eq. (4) to obtain reliable diffusion coef- ficients of some organic molecules [7]. Similar equations were used by Stevens and McKeithan to obtain the intrinsic reaction rate constants for the fluorescence quenching of 1 4-dihydroanthraqui- none and 1-aminoanthraquinone by N,N -dimethyl- 21 related to the internal reorganization energy (S=A~5J hQ) and is sensitive to changes in bond lengths and force constants during electron transfer. 3. Experimental All compounds and solvents were of highest avail- able purity. 1-cyanonaphthalene and 9,10-dicy- anoanthracene were recrystallized from methanol and toluene, respectively. The fluorescence spectra of the systems given in table 1 were obtained using a Spex Fluorolog 2 spec- trofluorimeter (model 11 lC) which was equipped with a multialkali R928 photomultiplier tube oper- ated as a quantum counter. The Stern Volmer plots were constructed from the integrals of the fluores- cence spectra that were corrected for the spectral sensitivity of the photomultiplier using a calibrated standard light source (Tungsten halogen lamp model 245C, L190 Optronic Laboratories, Inc.). The flu- orescence measurements were done with quencher concentrations up to 0.2 M and with fluorophore concentrations in the range of l0~ to to~ M. System a) aG~ (eV) I (os) k, <k,,> e) a (A) y (Ac ) 9,l0-DCA+I 1.09 15.3 20.5 84.6 5.5(0.4) 1.05(0.06) 9,IO-DCA+SCN 0.79 17.1 45.4 5.5(0.1) 1.04(0.04) 9,l0-DCA+Br 0.59 17.1 30.2 5.5(0.5) 1.17(0.02) l-CNN+1 1.0 9.3 27.1 103.8 6.1(0.2) 1,13(0.08) l-CNN+SCN 0.7 22.0 70.6 5.5(0.2) 1.20(0.22) t-CNN+Br 0.5 10.8 18.7 5.5(0.1) 1.00(0.09) p-Tcr+1 0.76 1.0 36.2 78.1 6.9(0.1) 1.40(0.12) p-Ter+SCN 0.46 15.2 23.8 5.5(0.1) 0.95(0.33) An+r 0.48 5.0 18.0 35.9 5.5(0.3) 0.92(0.38) An+SCN 0.18 4.6 4.3 5.5(0.4) 1.24(0.04) Bi+SCN 0.48 13.0 13.9 26.7 5.7(0.1) 1.90(0.07) Bi+Br 0.28 2.6 fl+SCN 0.2 6.7 7.0 8.4 5.7(0.1) 1.14(0.11) (10) Volume 211, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 6August1993 p-toluidine in acetonitrile [8] or aromatic hydro- carbons by CBr4 and CHBr3 in various solvents [9], assuming that the reaction takes place exclusively at the contact separation. On the other hand, the dependence of (k~~> 011 ESGe , may be calculated on the basis of theoretical expressions for electron transfer such as the one given by Onuchic [10] or the simpler one given by Jortner [11]. According to Jortner, the distance-dependent electron rate constant has the following form: f \112 k ( ) V( m)21 lt r ~ r, V2A(r)kT F [~G~+mhQ+2(r)]2 42(r)kT where V(r, tn)2=V(a)2exp[ y(r a)I exp( S) xSmfm! is called the modified electronic coupling matrix element, y is the scaling factor, a is the dis- tance of closest approach of reactants, A( r) is the sol- vent reorganization energy, ~Ge t is the free energy of the electron-transfer reaction, and hQ is an energy for the high-frequency vibrational modes of the reac- tants. The method used to calculate the parameters <k,,> and a is described in the text. The fluoresence lifetimes, 4, and the free energy of electron transfer, AG~,, were taken from ref. Calculations We use eq. (7) to calculate the concentration-de- pendent fluorescence quenching rate constants. Be- cause eq. (7) is a recursive equation (the right-hand expression depends explicity on k0 through the pa- rameter a, eq. (2)) an iterative procedure was needed to obtain self-consistent solutions, starting from kq([Q])=2X 10 M s (diffusion-con- trolled limit). Eq. (7) also contains the distance-de- pendent electron-transfer rate constant k ( r), which is determined by least-squares fitting to the experi- mental data. We used the Minuits subroutine from the Cern Library [12] by assuming the following form for k (r) [13]: k (r)=A exp[ y (r a)]. (Il) Theoretical expressions for the pre-exponential fac- torA have been given [10,11,14,15]. Thus we used three adjustable parameters, the preexponcntial fac- torA, the distance of closest approach a, and scaling factor y , which were determined by the least-squares fitting procedure. The calculations were made using a value of 4>< l0-~ cm2/s for the sum of the donor and the acceptor diffusion coefficients. This value is close to the sum of donor and acceptor diffusion coefficients for anthracene and iodide anion in methanol (3.7x l0~ cm2/s) at 294 K that was ob- tained from fluorescence decay functions [16]. The distance dependence given by eq. (11) cor- responds to a nonadiabatic description of the elec- tron-transfer process [14] which is acceptable in view of the short dielectric longitudinal relaxation time of acetonitrile (TL=O.S ps) [17]. Under these condi- tions the more general Onuchic equation [10] be- comes identical with the somewhat simpler Jortner equation [11]. The distance-averaged electron- transfer rate constants may be easily calculated using eq. (9), after fitting eq. (8) to the experimental rel- ative fluorescence intensities. 5. Discussion Fig. 1 shows as an example the experimental and calculated Stern Volmer plots for 9,1 0-DCA with 1, SCN, and Br as quenchers in acetonitrile. The <ks,> data, calculated by the above procedure, are Fig. I. Experimental (points) and calculated (lines) relative flu- orescence intensities as a function of quencher concentration for 9, lO-dicyanoanthracene in acetonitrile. collected in table 1. At strongly negative ~ the distance averaged electron-transfer rate constants, <k~~>, calculated from eq. (9) exceed the fluores- cence quenching rate constants, k0, and the differ- ences between the two are a function of AG~. In this thermodynamic region the fluorescence quenching is diffusion controlled. The scaling factors, y , obtained from the analysis are in the range 1.1 0.2 A , which is in agreement with results reported by Closs and Miller for elec- tron-transfer reactions in monomolecular donor ac- ceptor systems [13 J. The results for (Icet) are only marginally affected when y is kept at a fixed value of 1 A in the fitting procedure. Fig. 2 shows the dependence of log <1cc,) on AG~1. The points are the experimental results given in table 1. In addition we plotted the data from ref. [4] which are respresentative of fluorescence quenching rate constants in the endothermic region. In this case the observed fluorescence quenching rate constants are approximately equal to the distance- averaged electron-transfer rate constants (eq. (9)). The lines are the predictions given by eqs. (9) and (10) using the parameters given in the figure cap- tions. As we see from fig. 2, the theory does not de- scribe all the experimental results. For positive AG~ ~ another mechanism (external heavy atom ef- fect) must be additionally operative. Similar con- clusions were obtained from the analysis of fluores- cence decays of anthracene in the presence of iodide and thiocyanide in alcohols [16] and from temper- 10/I 0.00 0.05 0.10 0.15 IQI/M 23 Volume 211, number I CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 6August 1993 togl<k~,>J(s1W )1 1~G~1/eV Fig. 2. Distance-averaged electron-transfer rates, <k,,), calcu- lated from the experimental fluorescence quenching data as de- scribed in the text (circles) and the best fits to the Jortner theory, eqs.(9)and(1O)(lines).(I) V(a)=O.005leV,S=I.4,a=5.6 A fit of values at negative ~G~ (2) V(a)=0.02 eV, S=1.4, a= 5.6 A fit of values at positive ~ ature dependencies of fluorescence quenching rate constants of aromatic molecules by inorganic anions in methanol ethanol solutions [6]. How reliable are the intrinsic electron-transfer rate constants and the other parameters obtained from stationary fluorescence measurements using the Keizer procedure? A direct method to test the reli- ability of our results is to compare them with those obtained from time-resolved fluorescence data. Mataga and co-workers [181 have presented a flu- orescence decay analysis for some derivatives of an- thracene and several organic quenchers in acetoni- true, which yields the intrinsic electron-transfer rate constants in the exothermic region. The agreement between our estimates of the intrinsic electron-trans- fer rate constants for anthracene and p-dicyanob enzene (DCNB), maleic anhydride (MA), and phthalic anhydride (PA) as quenchers with those derived by time-resolved methods [18] is remark- able (table 2). loi 100 10~ F 3.0 Fig, 3. Dependence of the standard deviations for the fitted pa- rameters <k,,> (upper diagram) and D (lower diagram) using the quenching data for 9, lO-DCA and I . The other parameters were held fixed at D=4x I0~ cm2 s and a=5.5 A (upper), and (k,,> =8.46x 10105_I M~ and a=5.5 A (lower). Table 2 Comparison of intrinsic electron-transfer rate constants <k,,> obtained by different methods System L~G ,, (eV) <k,,> ~ (l010M~ s~ ) <k,,> b) (lO M s ) An+DCNB 0.41 3.42 3.09 An+PA 0.70 5.19 5.81 An+MA 1.17 13.3 12.4 ~ Calculated from nonexponential fluorescence decays [18]. b) Calculated from nonlinear S V dependencies (this work). -1.1 -0.8 0.5 -0.2 0.1 0.4 <k~X1O11I(M1s ) 102 3.5 4.0 4.5 flX105/(cni1c ) 24 Volume 211, number 1 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETFERS 6 August 1993 In all calculations we minimized the following function (squares of deviations) F= ~ (J~i_I ~?)2~ where I~J ~ and ~ are the calculated and experi- mental relative fluorescence intensities, respectively. Figs. 3 and 4 show the sensitivity of the function F Ofl <IC51> and D, keeping the other parameters fixed for 9,lO-DCA and 1 and for fluorene and SCN-. In the first system the quenching is essentially con- trolled by diffusion while in the second the quench- ing is controlled by the electron-transfer reaction. One would expect that in the second system the reaction rate should not be sensitive to D and in the fist this dependence should be high. This is indeed the case: for 9,lO-DCA and 1 the dependence on D is sharp, which allows us to determine the diffusion coeffi cient accurately, in contrast to the fluorene and SCN systems where this dependence is not as pronounced. 6. Conclusions The results from this work show that under well- defined circumstances the nonlinearities of Stern Yolmer plots may be used to obtain meaningful val- ues for the intrinsic electron-transfer rate constants. The technique described by Keizer is appropriate, provided that there is no ground-state pre-associa- tion of the fluorophores with the quencher mole- cules. If such molecular complexes form and do not fluoresce, this would also give rise to positive cur- vature of the Stern Volmer function. The simplest method to test whether such association occurs is to compare the Stern Volmer plots taken from inte- grated fluorescence intensities and from fluores- cence lifetimes (as zeroth moment of the decay func- tion). In the case of molecular associates I~/J will be greater than t~/T. Nonequilibrium distributions of the quencher molecules during the fluorescence lifetime leads to nonexponential fluorescence decays in the presence of quenchers. These so-called transient effects have been used [18] to estimate parameters describing transport (diffusion coefficients) and chemical re- action (intrinsic rate constants). This work shows that the same information may be obtained reliably from simple steady-state fluorescence quenching data. head.ce:title: Deriving intrinsic electron-transfer rates from nonlinear Stern—Volmer dependencies for fluorescence quenching of aromatic molecules by inorganic anions in acetonitrile

ce:affiliation.ce:textfn: Institut für Physikalische Chemie der Universität Basel, Klingelbergstrasse 80, CH-4056 Basel, Switzerland

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The fluorescence quenching of aromatic molecules by inorganic anions in acetonitrile was investigated by stationary fluorescence measurements. The dependence of the quenching rate constants, k q on the free energy of electron transfer, ΔG 0 et, obeys the well known Rehm—Weller expression which indicates that electron transfer is responsible for fluorescence quenching. Nonlinear Stern—Volmer behaviour was observed in many cases especially at very negative ΔG 0 et (< −0.7 eV). Distance-averaged electron-transfer rate constants, 〈k et〉, were determined from the concentration dependence of the fluorescence quenching rates using a procedure developed by Keizer. In three cases these values can be compared with those obtained by analysis of the transient effect seen directly in picosecond time-resolved fluorescence decay curves.
